transcript.transcript: Today is Tuesday, April 17th, 1990. I'm Nan Netherton interviewing Doctor Robert Hawkes, who is dean of the School of Continuing and Alternative Learning at George Mason University in Northern Virginia. Doctor Hawkes, could you start out by telling us something of your family background, where you were born and what your parents did and so on? Certainly. I'll be delighted to. I am a native, lifelong Virginian, and I was born January 27th, 1942, in Nottoway County, Virginia. I was born in the family home place which my family has owned for over 100 years. In fact, I was the last of a line of four males in the family to be born in that home in the same bedroom, I said, but not the same bed. My parents operated a family owned and run farm. They were very successful farmers. It's an irony to me that my generation, my brother and sister and I were the first of my family after the Civil War to go to college, so that it took my family exactly 100 years to restore its economic status after the Civil War. My parents did not go to college. My only brother went to Virginia Tech. I chose not to go to Virginia Tech, in part because I did not want to be Benjamin's younger brother. I had gone to a public school system in Nottoway County, Blackstone, that the high school had 200 students, and there were 30 in my graduating class. It was a small school, but I think a very, very good school. Uh, traditionally, the boys went off to Virginia Tech to study agriculture, engineering or business. I was leaning toward a ministerial vocation at the time and went to Randolph-Macon. We were Methodists, and Randolph-Macon was the Methodist College in Virginia. There my freshman year, my favorite teacher and one who later became my advisor, was a man named Doctor George Brown Oliver. And he had a deep influence on me and persuaded me, through his good teaching and his interest in me, to major in history. And it was my favorite subject my freshman year at college. I graduated from Randolph-Macon in 1964. I was pleased to be in the honors program there in history, which I found out after I was invited to join. That meant that you took additional coursework. But I think it was good for me. Well, you mentioned that your generation was the first to attend college since the Civil War. Did you know of antecedents your ancestors who had attended college before the Civil War? Yes. I had a grandparent on my mother's side, a Captain Stephen White, who had been to VMI. And on my father's side, I can't name a particular one, but Robert Alexander Hawks fought for the Confederacy as well and came from a medium sized plantation family in southern Virginia. Mm. Mm. Uh, what? You said you were the younger brother. Does that mean you were the youngest of the three? No. I'm a middle child. I have a younger sister who, uh, attended Mary Washington College who now lives on part of the home place and who is also a teacher and teaches in the public school system in Nottoway County. Still maintaining high standards in Nottoway County public schools. Um, did you have any unusual experiences other than your change of direction at Randolph-Macon in high school or in college, which reinforced your choice? I think there were. I have often marveled at how we go in a certain direction. When I went to the University of Virginia in 1964 as an entering graduate history student, I, of course, came from a very limited financial background, and I had no money really to continue in graduate school. I had gotten a small scholarship from the University of Virginia, which had determined my choice in going there. My first choice had really been Duke, in part because that's where Doctor Oliver, my undergraduate advisor, had urged me to go. But finances dictated that if I were to go anywhere, it would be the University of Virginia. I remember unpacking in the dormitory and going over to see the man who was then chairman of the history department, and who became another major influence in my life, a doctor, Edward Younger. As it turned out, he was an Arkansas farm boy and who had grown up on the farm. I remember some interesting conversations we had about the nature of mules when you were plowing a field, and how stubborn they could be, and how much they had their own will and determination to plow the field the way they thought it ought to be. Plywood. Well, I went over to see Mr. Younger and one of my first meetings with him. There were a line of new graduate students waiting to see him, and I told Mr. Younger, I'm here. I have unpacked, but unless I can get additional aid of some kind, I cannot remain. And I remember him saying to me, Mr. Hawks, the dean of the School of Continuing Education, has just telephoned me and he has a half time position coordinator of World history and you happen, Mr. Hawks, to be the first graduate student who has come in asking for a job since that telephone call. So I will give that job to you. I said, Mr. Younger, what is continuing education? And from that point on, my career assumed a very pleasing dual nature, and that is being both a historian and a continuing educator. I often wondered what would have happened if the graduate student waiting in front of me, who saw Mr. Younger ahead of me, had asked for a job. I'm not sure. Oh. That's fascinating. Um, now, you took two degrees at Virginia. That is correct. But in between, you did something else. Well, I worked in a number of part time positions. One was co-ordinator of history for what was then called the School of General Studies, which was really continuing education. Another was assistant to the dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, a position I took when Mr. Younger became dean of the graduate school at the University of Virginia. There I ran a lecture series and did other things again of a continuing education nature. I worked on my master's on the gubernatorial term of Harry Flood Byrd senior, who was governor of Virginia from 1926 to 1930. Certainly the strongest and most influential governor that Virginia has had in this century, a man who went on to the United States Senate in 1933 and remained there until a year with within his death, 1965 and then death in 1966. He was a fascinating subject because he headed Virginia's Democratic organization, and my master's thesis was on that topic. Then I left the University of Virginia in 1969, chose George Mason College, largely at the urging of Mr. Younger and Doctor Robert J. Harris, who was a political scientist and dean of the faculty at the University of Virginia. Where was the college at the time you joined the faculty? When I came in 1969. My role. Excuse me. My role was to to coordinate between the University of Virginia Extension Center, which was located in Falls Church and was a branch of the School of General Studies of the University of Virginia and George Mason College. That was 1969. At the time George Mason College had just graduated its first baccalaureate class in 1968, they had decided to become a four year institution and had been authorized to in 1966, so the first class was 68. I joined George Mason the following year. There were about 1200 students. It was entirely a daytime liberal arts program. Uh, the University of Virginia Extension Center met in high schools, had been in Northern Virginia since 1947, had very extensive programs, but did not offer degrees, so that I hope to make it easier for many of those adults to move to George Mason to complete degree programs. That was part of my role then. I also taught history and taught United States Southern History. Since I had concluded, based on my graduate years, that the South was what I really knew and understood and enjoyed. Well was the college at that time on its present campus and just the first buildings. It had moved to Fairfax in 1964. When I came here, there were the four original buildings, the lecture hall and the front part of the library. Now, a tale that I was never able to substantiate was that the architecture for the lecture hall matched all of the other buildings at Clinch Valley College of the University of Virginia, and that at Clinch Valley College. All of the buildings had that architecture, except for one lecture hall, which looked like the buildings at George Mason. I've often wondered if indeed the designs were switched, and we got there lecture hall, and they got ours. Also, the front part of the library had been built what is currently now the reference room. The original plans for that, uh, demonstration were designed so that there would be a reflecting pool around the front of that. That was eliminated in the final planning because of the fear that students would constantly be pushing each other into the pool, putting soapsuds. But it still does have a sort of decline or a sort of a. Moat. A moat type of area around there. Soon after I came on, a beautiful grove of trees were cut down to begin construction of what became Thompson Hall, and I remember at the time, the environmentalists protesting at the loss of those trees. Goodness knows they had little idea of what would be coming in the next 20 years. More trees would be going in the next 20 years, right? Yeah. Now, I noticed that you went to an institute at Harvard. Uh, had you gotten into continuing education at George Mason by that time? Yes. I had long been in continuing education. I functioned in my dual role between George Mason and the University of Virginia Extension Center until 1973. In 1972, a very momentous event occurred for George Mason, and that is it became a separate freestanding public university, separate from its mother institution, the University of Virginia, which meant that my coordinating role was limited, certainly in its future. In the spring of 1973, Doctor Robert Krug, who was then vice president for academic affairs of the new university, asked me to become full time in developing continuing education at George Mason. And that fall I, in a part time position, continuing to teach in the history department and with a half time secretary, went around to department chairs and asked them if they would consider offering courses in the evening. some did. Of course, some responded that George Mason, being a suburban institution, was not suited for night school, that downtown Washington schools such as George Washington would be able to do that. But we would never be able to develop evening programs at George Mason. Well, my strategy essentially was to work with those departments who wanted to work with me in developing an undergraduate evening session, and almost immediately it caught on and flourished and grew very, very rapidly, so that today, the undergraduate evening session represents one of the very strong components of the university. We have eight undergraduate majors available entirely in the evening. When you consider graduate work as well, of course, 11 a.m. and 7:20 p.m. in the evening of the two peak class scheduling times now for George Mason. And from that beginning and I was at the time, I remember, uh, Bob Krug called me in and said, I'd like for you to develop continuing education now for this new college, George, a new university, George Mason University. He said, think about a title. And so I came back to see him in several days, and I said, I'd like for it to be the office of evening session and special programs, and I'd be the director and doctor. Krug, who was very supportive of adult evening programs, much more so than I had realized, said Bob. I think you ought to think of a broader title so you can look to expansion, something that's more inclusive of off campus programs or enrollment for students who are non-degree or. And he said, what about the term extended studies? That's more inclusive. And I thought he is correct. So it became the Office of Extended Studies. And it was that until Doctor George Johnson came in the summer of 1980. I was able to go to at George Mason's funded me for that. The university, a special summer institute conducted at Harvard University for continuing educators. It's a special intensive program to help you look at what's happening in the field, management and other types of things. That was a nice refresher almost at mid-career or well into my career. By 1980, uh, continuing education had, I think, changed the face of George Mason forever. By 1980, the typical George Mason student was an older student. The average age was certainly close to 26 or 27 by that point. Evening had become a peak scheduling cup time. Adult students, who certainly represented the Lifelong Learning Society and were certainly on the edge of a new future in American higher education, had already come to give George Mason a very rich diversity in terms of the experiences brought to the typical classroom and the faculty here. For the most part, I would say welcome. The adult students found them challenging, enjoyed having them. I had remarkably little resistance from faculty in bringing adult students here. I think we were very fortunate in that George Mason was growing very rapidly, and in the decade of the 70s and even into the 80s, we had a relatively young faculty, many who were certainly open to change and open to the challenges that mature adults who have great experience can bring to a classroom. Could you give me a definition of continuing education, or would you want to say that the definition has changed over the years? The definition has changed over the years. I recently was privileged to go to a annual ceremony at George Mason, and when they recognized many employees for five years of service, ten 1520 I received a 20 year recognition at the last ceremony. And in reflecting on that, I said to the president before the ceremony began, I have considered several times in my career moving and leaving George Mason, but the institution moved faster than I did, and in reflection, I have been at 20 different institutions. Continuing education, likewise, has changed very, very significantly. Back in those days, my primary interest was in developing credit programs at times and places, primarily in the evening that would be accessible to adult students. I think the role of continuing education today, when the school of continuing and Alternative learning directly touches almost a third of George Mason. Student body is to look to a future in which I think education will come in many different forms. Parts of it will be closely intense personal relationships between professor and students in small seminars and interactions on papers and readings similar to colloquies and seminars and internships such as we have today. Other parts of education will come by satellite to small groups that meet in clusters all over Northern Virginia, and who socialize as a class, maybe with a student leader while the material comes by satellite through film. Many courses will be offered by video tape or by video disk on the computer by interactive uh uh, two way satellite programs or other types of technical mechanisms, so that I think. College in the future will be a variety of learning experiences to meet the kind. Of lifestyles that we are evolving so that it we're beginning to see, for example. At George Mason that it makes little sense to have a student body of 20,000. Drive here on a daily basis. Why not take that education out to them? Utilizing the kinds of technology that was never available to us before, and that Northern Virginia is really evolving as a network, a series of nodes, almost, for lack of a better term, urban villages. And they're not villages in the sense you and I think of villages, but concentrations of commercial law, industrial law, research activity, and residential communities and neighborhoods and centers growing from, of course, historic antecedents which are still there in abundance, but as a new urban center that is really unlike a typical downtown. Nevertheless, it's a highly sophisticated center with very highly educated persons and the challenge of George Mason. And I want continuing education to be the catalyst and leader in that is how to preserve our core, to preserve our integrity as a center of learning and culture for this community. And yet at the same time, being very accessible in an age where lifestyles are very busy, where people are very mobile, and where I think in a quality way, we can bring knowledge to them using technology. It's probably the greatest challenge we've ever faced. Do you foresee that possibly the university will utilize space in shopping centers, as libraries have been trying to do in the county system? Envision that. One of the things that I have advocated that is not original with me, and none of these ideas can I claim credit for. I try to be eclectic, picking the best from many things. And George Johnson, of course, has played a very, very strong leadership role here at the institution. And many of the ideas come from him. Uh, I have advocated that we develop what I call the convenience store or 7-Eleven approach to serving Northern Virginia, and that is to have a number of relatively small All centers that are very conveniently located, preferably very near exit ramps off of the Beltway or interstates that might be commercial buildings during the day. But at night, those conference rooms, those meeting places would become classes for George Mason students. And that we might have one way video from the main campus so that by microwave or by satellite, the students there could get a picture on a screen of the professor lied. And then by telephone line, we'd have two way audio so that there could be an audio exchange back and forth. Those smaller sections meeting in satellite locations all over the region, would have their own social identity, so that those students might meet 30 minutes before the main class Us begins to organize their thinking, to work together. I think that combines technology and the personal interrelationships which I believe are so important to learning. In other words, I think the secret that we're striving for is to use technology to improve the quality of relationships, not to depersonalize it, and at the same time to improve the convenience to people to continually acquire more education. I see in your description, and maybe this is a misinterpretation, that the students might be closer, but it seems to me that professors would be more remote. In some instances. You might have some contact with your professor over satellite or by telephone line, but I think it would also allow the opportunity for the professor. For example, if a course were on videotape, the professor might instead then spend his time rather than lecturing to a section of 300 students, which unfortunately occurs. Now, that professor might put those lectures on videotape and instead spend his time meeting with small groups of the class in less frequent sessions, so that you might not meet with the professor, but 2 or 3 times during the semester. But it would be in a group of 4 or 5 of you, so that I would hope we could improve the quality of that time you spend with the professor. While certainly there are certain non-verbal communication that occurs in a section of 300 students, I believe that that is not the. My own belief is that that is not the optimal educational situation, and that indeed students need more contact with professors. Hopefully it would be, although technology might mean that it would be less frequent, I would hope the quality of that time together would be greatly enhanced. And that professor might, from time to time, move himself from one of those satellite locations to another. What attributes do you feel equipped you for the continuing education field? Besides your mentors who urged you to enter it? Well, I, uh, continuing education is an interesting field. I think it's very characteristic of the future of higher education, in the sense that those of us who are in Scoring, continuing ed come out of many different disciplines, and much of the future of higher education, I think, will be interdisciplinary. One of the earliest things we developed here in continuing education was a Bachelor of Individualized Studies. And then in 1978, when President Johnson changed us to a division of Continuing Education and elevated my position to the dean's level, we were able to begin work on a master of Arts in Interdisciplinary studies. I think that that an adult educator is someone who has to read and study how adults learn, and to realize that adults never lose their ability to learn, that your mind and mine remains as sharp as it ever was. In fact, on those rare instances when professors have said to me, older students cannot learn. And that's only been rare. My response has been, what about yourself? Are you still capable of learning? And I think that pretty much summarizes how I feel. I think you have to realize that learning is a partnership, and that most people get out of learning what they put into it, and that the role of a good teacher is to stimulate an interest in the subject, to stimulate enthusiasm and a desire to find out more. I think, uh, to work with adults, to be a continuing educator, you have to be open to innovation. You have to be a rebel against, uh, accepted practice and conventional wisdom. You have to look at and be interested in what a person knows more than where and how they learned it. And I think continuing education is coming of age because of the fact that economics, mobility, other things make it probably highly unlikely that we will carry out higher education the way we did for the last 100 years. As President Johnson again points out, higher education has worked well in the past 100 years, serving an industrial age because it is an exact model of that. It's like an assembly line. Everybody enters at 18, they go down a four year assembly line. There are certain options you can have put on it. There are different colors of the models, just like different degree programs. And four years later they come off the assembly line prepared for life or 100,000 miles or whatever it is. People tend to not realize the semester hour as a standardized part for the assembly line is only a little over 100 years old. It is not a sacred phenomena in higher education, nor our majors, nor our 120 semester hour degree programs. None of that is sacred. They are convenient, useful inventions to serve an industrial age. Do you have a set of profiles of your student groups who participate in the continuing education program? Yes, we have conducted quite a bit of study of who comes back to school. One verse significant group that characterizes George Mason are college graduates who have moved to the Washington area to begin careers and now want to return and on a part time evening basis, earn a master's degree. That's why George Mason is almost one third graduate, which is an unusually large number of graduate students. Most institutions are more like 10% rather than 33% graduate. And I think that's strengthened this institution. Those people tend to be in their mid 20s to mid 30s who are returning to gain a first professional degree to update some of their knowledge, particularly in areas like engineering and artificial intelligence where a degree is obsolete within 4 or 5 years. And as you know, Northern Virginia has become in many ways a major information center. And the information Industries, particularly in Fairfax County and the Tysons Corridor, are very significant part of our economy and bring very highly educated people to our region. Another very significant group are people who are returning to finish college. They are often people with two years of college who dropped out, either for economic reasons or to begin, families, and who now are in a situation in terms of their own lives to resume school. Uh, curiously enough, many of these adults are people who come in the daytime. Many of them are women who have the middle of the day as their time. They have family obligations. Later in the day, they can come to school between the time their spouses and children leave for school and work, and they get home at the end of the day. There are people who are very serious about their studies. Sometimes the 18 year olds feel they skew the grades in there because they get such extremely good grades. I think they add a very rich diversity to the classroom. I think that anybody who looks at the world today realizes that in an international age, societies populations will be very diverse in terms of age, culture, religious background, ethnic background. We've already begun to duplicate that at George Mason. We're also bringing in many of the people who have added to the richness of Northern Virginia, such as Hispanic people who have come from Latin American countries or the Vietnamese refugees, many who as older students or who are working for economic reasons come to take 1 or 2 courses at a time. I call these people the New Americans, and they will characterize much of the future of America. Higher education has a poor record of serving these important new groups. Again, George Mason, often through continuing education, is building a real base of experience and service with these groups that will rapidly enter the mainstream as a very important part of our society. The typical adult student here is one who's coming to finish a degree program, or to change a career, or simply to get updated. We have done, for example, a lot of work in encouraging people with nursing backgrounds to return to the job market. Nurses are often people who drop out for other careers or because of family responsibilities. Now, with the critical shortage of people in health care fields, we feel we play an important role by making it convenient for them to return to their careers and to return to service in their field. And we've developed, for example, special continuing education programs that allow nurses who graduated from nursing school 10 or 15 years ago to come back and very quickly get up to date on the new developments that have occurred in their field while they were taking a break from it. Uh, that we have mainstreamed adult students here at George Mason. You can go day or evening, full time or part time. We have not segregated them off into a separate For university, college or night school in the sense that the barriers are not there. 1st May register any way he or she chooses, regardless of age, so that there are no lines here. And the more the mix, the more heterogeneous the mix in the classroom, the healthier we feel it is. Do you still have a nursing school for undergraduates here? Yes, we do, and it's a very strong program and a very large program. Again, it it works with their two paths within that nursing school. One is the traditional full time student in a four year baccalaureate nursing program. The other is a program for people who blend in after the equivalent of two years of college work, often from the old university or the old hospital. Schools of nursing, as you may remember, that exists no more. Those were not typically regionally accredited institutions, but we have developed programs that through testing, we accept that work. And those people blend in so that if someone graduated a number of years ago from a hospital school of nursing such as Alexandria Hospital had, for example, we can take advantage of that knowledge and make it so that person doesn't have to start over. You mentioned the ethnic character of the students in continuing education. Do you have any statistical analyses of sex participation? Are there more women than men? Is it evenly divided? More men than women? There are generally more women than men, in part because, you know, women are entering the job market, both out of economic pressure and out of new values in very large numbers. And women are the ones that are more likely to come back to complete a degree program, to shift fields to prepare themselves. Often now, after their families are grown and they're empty nesters, they're ready to come back and do something very constructive and productive for our society. I think it is reflective of our society being more conscious of the fact that artificial barriers have created a tremendous loss to our society in terms of talent. I think about the irony of my childhood in which the teachers I had were brilliant people, and I give them a lot of credit for my subsequent success. If I look back at Nottoway and Blackstone. In those days, there were only certain acceptable jobs for women. They could not become lawyers. They could not become physicians. They were not allowed to run businesses for the most part. So those brilliant women did the only thing that was acceptable to them, and that was they went to teach and we got a bargain in terms of that. Now, of course, it's much healthier today in that those talents can be spread out. Although I think one of the ironies is, is that, uh, public school systems don't have the captive brilliance they had at one time, meaning that now that talent is free to go to many other places and often does. But I think one of the roles continuing education has and is certainly had at George Mason, is discovering and developing untapped Brilliance and untapped talent that, because of cultural and social reasons, was not used fully in our society. And I think we are already seeing the benefit of that. You mentioned in passing a little while ago something about following the students after they left the university and this program. Do you? What techniques do you have for that? Is there anything formal we survey? Yes, we do surveys of alumni, particularly in our non-traditional degree programs, such as the Bachelor of Individualized Studies and the Master of Arts and Interdisciplinary Studies, both of which, of course, are here in the School of Continuing and Alternative Learning. Uh, we quizzed them on things like, are you satisfied with the program you got? Did it accomplish what you wanted in terms of personal enrichment or On career development. And those surveys give us an affirmative yes to those programs. Very strong. Affirmative. Yes. In fact, to give you several examples, the former chairman of the Board of Supervisors for Prince William County, Mr. Edwin King, who is still on the board, is a man who came back, had dropped out after several years of college, found our Bachelor of Individualized Studies program to suit his needs perfectly. Graduated from George Mason with that program. Another example is James Corrigan, who had jumped had dropped out of George Mason, was an old student government president in the early 1970s, returned to college in the late 70s, graduated in 1981, and has now pledged and given the largest donation to George Mason of any graduate in the history of this university. Now, this was a returning adult student who, in his earlier traditional age student age career, had actually failed out of George Mason returns. Now heads a very successful company. Key research in California and is the major alumni supporter of George Mason University. But another typical example is Melanie Jackson, who is the mayor of the city of Manassas Park. Another adult student at George Mason who graduated in the Bachelor of Individualized Studies. These are all people who are visibly making a significant contribution to society, who, through special programs we developed, were able to come back, get the kind of background they felt they needed as mature adults there only the more visible ones. That's a nice group of success stories. Does the field seem to be growing and evolving nationwide and here, do you think? Where would you place George Mason in the spectrum of the nationwide move toward this kind of move away from industrial and moving into the information society? I think George Mason, mostly through bold, innovative thinking and action, has placed itself at the leadership in this group. For example, our Bachelor of Individualized Studies was one of the first such degrees in the country. This year, in several weeks, we will host our eighth annual National Conference on Non-traditional Interdisciplinary Programs. At that conference, representatives from over 100 colleges and universities will come to a conference run by George Mason to share experiences, to learn from us what we have done in innovative, interdisciplinary programs. This is a national conference that George Mason has run for its peers for eight years now in a row, but we've done it in other fields of endeavor. As you know, a very recent survey of law school deans ranked our law school the most up and coming in the country. We have certainly an economics program that's nationally known. But again, these are programs that have been developed outside of conventional wisdom and higher education. Will other institutions duplicate George Mason? I think yes, they have, and they will as much as they can. I think that being at the formative stage we were and being in such a supportive region was important for us. You know, Northern Virginians are highly educated persons. The typical Northern Virginian has two years of college. They're people who appreciate the role of education and the quality of life. If you look at the quality of the public schools in Northern Virginia, the quality of the public libraries, we are we have a very supportive population. I think, again, President Johnson correctly perceived years ago that the typical state university would not suffice for northern than Virginians, that our populace wouldn't tolerate mediocrity in higher education any more that they than they do in anything else. And certainly time seems to have demonstrated that he is correct. So that we, because we believe our public wants it, have tried to be a bold, innovative, experimental institution and yet to give more than usual attention to the quality of what we do. What will the FY 1991 budget be for your department? My unit? We we have concerns for another year, in part because of our length as this whole region is to the federal government and to its spending. ironically enough, continuing education at George Mason is a combination of the state budget as other schools are funded, and we are a very entrepreneurial unit. We do several million dollars a year of contract training, both for private business and government. These are agencies and companies that come to us and contract with us to do certain programs for their employees. Uh, some of that training is being cut back, in part because of the reduction in federal spending. I don't think we'll have a great downfall. Our budget is about 3 million a year. I think we will go through some temporary adjustment. Uh, we have built continuing ed from nothing to about a 3 million a year budget or more. Uh, I predict that in many ways, much of the rest of the university will adopt many of the things we have tried to do, and that is a sign of success for us. And I view continuing educators like pioneers or frontiers, men and women. We move out on the edge when we get to many neighbors. When we see smoke rising from other chimneys, we move further out. If much of the university adopts our entrepreneurial spirit, if they adopt our interdisciplinary thrust, if they're gladly willing to assume direction of evening and weekend programs and technologically delivered instruction, then we view that as a compliment, and we gladly turn that over to the more traditional units. We're the people in higher education who hit the beaches first. We're the ones who cut the leads. Who? Stay out front. I hope we'll continue to do that. How far removed from the so-called classical education are your programs? I think we are pretty far ahead at George Mason, both in individualized studies and in many of the interdisciplinary programs that other units have developed, some of which we have lent support to. A good example is our center in Conflict resolution with its graduate programs. I can remember when two people came to George Mason who were interested in conflict resolution, and I'm delighted that Continuing Ed was one of the units that listened to them, sponsored their courses, invested in them, thought they were a good bet. That bet has paid off. Now they're located now in the College of Arts and Sciences. They're a full blown center? We take great pride in that success. I think George Mason, particularly as it moves to a distributed mode as it moves away from the traditional type of student body, looks more like the University of the 21st century. I think we've come here to recognize that as valuable as a cloistered monastic type of higher education was, as much nostalgia as we feel for those ivy covered walls, that the future holds a different kind of institution. And while some institutions certainly can look and dwell on their heritage and what they do well and probably will continue to do well, we want to be in a less secure position. What improvements in public school preparation from kindergarten to the 12th grade are needed to prepare students for better performance at higher education levels. Surely you've had some experience with frustration and perhaps inadequacies that the students themselves have experienced entering this new level of pursuit, both undergraduate and graduate? Well, I have a great prejudice as a continuing educator and an adult educator. I often believe that college is wasted on the young. I deal very often with adults who said to me, I didn't appreciate this when I was 18 or 19 or 20. I didn't, I wasn't interested in it. I was going out of social pressure because all of my friends were, or my family felt I should. Uh, now that I know why I'm doing it and what I need. It's very different. I think that we are in an age where we ought to justly return to more rigour in terms of our expectations of students, that I think we have been through an age in education where we felt that people shouldn't have as much expected of them. I think that the public schools, too, have gotten saddled with unjustly many of the most serious problems in society, such as drug abuse, is a good example. I'm not sure public schools are funded or equipped to solve that problem for society. I think it's going to take more work from all of us. I think, too, that we need to be more. I think technology will allow us to give more individualized, Realize customized attention to persons. I know that may be a kind of irony, but I think it ought to enable us to work more and more, one on one, so that the parts of education that can be done in a mass way can be done, not again to depersonalize it, but to allow us to take each person as they come out of high school, test and work with them on verbal skills, on math skills, on other kinds of things, so that individual programming will allow a student to come into a feel at just the level he and she is at, you know, higher education, just like public education, aims at the middle point in a class of 30 some people. I think technology, I think advancing lifestyles. I think information age computers, if you will, is going to allow us to give more individual attention so that that person who's a little bit ahead doesn't get frustrated and bored, or that person who's a little bit behind doesn't get lost. I think we need to work more in a partnership with public schools. I think we need to view all of education as one stream, and I think we need to view it more and more, which I think will be able to of assessing a particular person's needs and having special programs on the shelves, if you will, that we can pull off, that starts that person right at the level he or she is at. I'm optimistic about the future. Frankly, I think those of us who are professors have got to learn to do many things in different ways. I think we've got to have a different view of the people we're working with. Uh. I'm optimistic. I think George Mason has come a long way. I think our greatest challenges are ahead of us. In an age of shrinking government expenditures, in an age where the economy will probably not have as much affluence as we share more in a world society with other parts of the world. I think the challenge is how do we keep our region competitive? How do we remain interactive? How do we meet a great diversity of people at the point they are at? And we're already debating and thinking about answers to that here? We're already experimenting. Uh, my school continuing in alternative learning is already funding several prototype experimental types of courses that will use video disc will world views, uh, computer programs to do certain portions again of the learning so that it'll be a smorgasbord approach. So you're thinking that where you find weaknesses, uh, they can be strengthened and where you find special interests, they can be catered to? Yes. And I think we do. I think we have come out of a period in which education, particularly at the primary, elementary, secondary level, has faced some unprecedented challenges. They have been subjected to a lot of criticism. They have been asked to take on much of the role that used to occur in community settings, in homes and churches and other places. I think that they've faced the turbulence of a changing society, both in its composition and its ethical background and the kinds of issues that face young people. I think we've learned a lot from that experience. I think we've had some failures. I think we're ready to reassess where we're at, and I think higher education wants to work more with them. Our dean of education here at George Mason has an interesting proposal to dissolve his school physically and move it into the school system so that the professors have offices right down the hall from the the elementary classroom. Uh, it's a novel concept. It's a kind of creative thinking that we try to foster here at George Mason. We may never be able to do it, but I think that's a beginning step of recognizing that partnership and recognizing that learning takes place other than across a lectern. What about the general philosophy at George Mason University? You were mentioning some resistance on the part of some deans. I guess it was of different schools in adopting the night school offerings. Do you feel many of them have come around, and do you feel that the administration generally supports your adventurous experiments and your successes. Not only supports it, they're part of it. Uh, George Johnson has been a very strong leader at George Mason and has been very much the instigator of this kind of, uh, innovative, creative thinking. I think those of us who are still here and in leadership positions or ones who agree with him and who fully support that, and I think that, uh, that whole philosophy that we need to Leap frog into the 21st century that rather than to become a poor model of older, established institutions, we need to take some risk to try to anticipate the future, knowing we will have some failures in trying to be an example of what schools will be in the future, rather than a poor copy of what very good schools were in the past. I think Northern Virginia, which had a dearth of higher education but a very sympathetic, sophisticated population, was the ideal environment. If you can imagine strong seed being planted in the most fertile soil you can imagine. Then we have days when we think, how could George Mason have been any less than it is? And then there are days when we struggle to try to be out front to meet the challenges of this region and to stretch ourselves just as far as we possibly can. I wouldn't have it any other way. I think that it one could be in higher education in the 1970s and 1980s, and you wanted to be somewhere where there was change. And I happen to believe that there is no growth where there is no change. I also believe that there is no life after growth. Then I think you couldn't have picked a better place than George Mason. And to Bill continuing, Ed, just as I thought it ought to be in this time frame, has been, I'm sure, one of the most unique privileges. That's a wonderful way to conclude an interesting interview. Thank you, Doctor Hawks. Thank you.

lines.line: > The speaker, a lifelong Virginian, was born into a family that owned a farm for over 100 years. He was the last of four males born in the same family home. His parents were successful farmers, and he was part of the first generation in his family to attend college post-Civil War, marking a significant economic recovery for his family. He attended a small public school and chose not to follow the traditional path to Virginia Tech, opting instead for Randolph-Macon due to his interest in a ministerial vocation.

metadata.title: Background and Early Education
metadata.synopsis: The speaker, a lifelong Virginian, was born into a family that owned a farm for over 100 years. He was the last of four males born in the same family home. His parents were successful farmers, and he was part of the first generation in his family to attend college post-Civil War, marking a significant economic recovery for his family. He attended a small public school and chose not to follow the traditional path to Virginia Tech, opting instead for Randolph-Macon due to his interest in a ministerial vocation.

lines.line: > While initially leaning towards a ministerial vocation, the speaker was deeply influenced by Dr. George Brown Oliver during his time at Randolph-Macon, which led him to major in history. His interest in history was sparked by his favorite subject and the encouragement from his advisor.

metadata.title: College Education and Influences
metadata.synopsis: While initially leaning towards a ministerial vocation, the speaker was deeply influenced by Dr. George Brown Oliver during his time at Randolph-Macon, which led him to major in history. His interest in history was sparked by his favorite subject and the encouragement from his advisor.

lines.line: > The speaker recounts his transition to graduate studies at the University of Virginia, driven by financial constraints and a scholarship. He describes a pivotal moment when a job opportunity in continuing education was offered to him just as he needed it, setting his career path forward.

metadata.title: Graduate Studies and Career Beginnings
metadata.synopsis: The speaker recounts his transition to graduate studies at the University of Virginia, driven by financial constraints and a scholarship. He describes a pivotal moment when a job opportunity in continuing education was offered to him just as he needed it, setting his career path forward.

lines.line: > The speaker discusses his various roles at the University of Virginia before moving to George Mason College. His responsibilities included coordinating history programs and assisting deans, which equipped him with the experience necessary for his later focus on continuing education.

metadata.title: Transition to George Mason University
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses his various roles at the University of Virginia before moving to George Mason College. His responsibilities included coordinating history programs and assisting deans, which equipped him with the experience necessary for his later focus on continuing education.

lines.line: > The speaker details his efforts in developing continuing education at George Mason, starting from persuading departments to offer evening courses. This initiative rapidly expanded, reflecting the growing demand and changing demographics of the student body, which increasingly comprised older students and working adults.

metadata.title: Development of Continuing Education
metadata.synopsis: The speaker details his efforts in developing continuing education at George Mason, starting from persuading departments to offer evening courses. This initiative rapidly expanded, reflecting the growing demand and changing demographics of the student body, which increasingly comprised older students and working adults.

lines.line: > Reflecting on his long career, the speaker notes the significant changes in continuing education, emphasizing its growing importance and integration into the main educational framework of George Mason University. He highlights the diversity and adaptability of programs that cater to non-traditional students and working professionals.

metadata.title: Evolution of Continuing Education
metadata.synopsis: Reflecting on his long career, the speaker notes the significant changes in continuing education, emphasizing its growing importance and integration into the main educational framework of George Mason University. He highlights the diversity and adaptability of programs that cater to non-traditional students and working professionals.

lines.line: > The speaker envisions a future where education is more accessible through technology, suggesting the use of satellite classes and online platforms to reach students. He advocates for a blend of technology and personal interaction to enhance the educational experience and adapt to the needs of a diverse student population.

metadata.title: Future of Education and Technology
metadata.synopsis: The speaker envisions a future where education is more accessible through technology, suggesting the use of satellite classes and online platforms to reach students. He advocates for a blend of technology and personal interaction to enhance the educational experience and adapt to the needs of a diverse student population.

lines.line: # Personal Attributes and Philosophy in Education

> The speaker discusses the qualities necessary for success in continuing education, such as openness to innovation and a focus on the practical knowledge of students rather than their academic background. He emphasizes the importance of adapting educational practices to meet the needs of adult learners and the evolving job market.

metadata.title: Personal Attributes and Philosophy in Education
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses the qualities necessary for success in continuing education, such as openness to innovation and a focus on the practical knowledge of students rather than their academic background. He emphasizes the importance of adapting educational practices to meet the needs of adult learners and the evolving job market.

lines.line: > The speaker reflects on the broader challenges facing education, from public schools to higher education. He suggests more rigorous expectations and individualized learning approaches to better prepare students for the demands of modern society and the workforce. He also highlights the need for closer collaboration between different educational levels to create a more integrated learning experience.

metadata.title: Challenges and Opportunities in Education
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on the broader challenges facing education, from public schools to higher education. He suggests more rigorous expectations and individualized learning approaches to better prepare students for the demands of modern society and the workforce. He also highlights the need for closer collaboration between different educational levels to create a more integrated learning experience.

His parents were successful farmers, and he was part of the first generation in his family to attend college post-Civil War, marking a significant economic recovery for his family. He attended a small public school and chose not to follow the traditional path to Virginia Tech, opting instead for Randolph-Macon due to his interest in a ministerial vocation.

> While initially leaning towards a ministerial vocation, the speaker was deeply influenced by Dr. George Brown Oliver during his time at Randolph-Macon, which led him to major in history. His interest in history was sparked by his favorite subject and the encouragement from his advisor.

> The speaker recounts his transition to graduate studies at the University of Virginia, driven by financial constraints and a scholarship. He describes a pivotal moment when a job opportunity in continuing education was offered to him just as he needed it, setting his career path forward.

> The speaker discusses his various roles at the University of Virginia before moving to George Mason College. His responsibilities included coordinating history programs and assisting deans, which equipped him with the experience necessary for his later focus on continuing education.

> The speaker details his efforts in developing continuing education at George Mason, starting from persuading departments to offer evening courses. This initiative rapidly expanded, reflecting the growing demand and changing demographics of the student body, which increasingly comprised older students and working adults.

> Reflecting on his long career, the speaker notes the significant changes in continuing education, emphasizing its growing importance and integration into the main educational framework of George Mason University. He highlights the diversity and adaptability of programs that cater to non-traditional students and working professionals.

> The speaker envisions a future where education is more accessible through technology, suggesting the use of satellite classes and online platforms to reach students. He advocates for a blend of technology and personal interaction to enhance the educational experience and adapt to the needs of a diverse student population.
# Personal Attributes and Philosophy in Education

> The speaker discusses the qualities necessary for success in continuing education, such as openness to innovation and a focus on the practical knowledge of students rather than their academic background. He emphasizes the importance of adapting educational practices to meet the needs of adult learners and the evolving job market.

> The speaker reflects on the broader challenges facing education, from public schools to higher education. He suggests more rigorous expectations and individualized learning approaches to better prepare students for the demands of modern society and the workforce. He also highlights the need for closer collaboration between different educational levels to create a more integrated learning experience.
